conclusion: To determine if the thermal motion of gas molecules becomes more intense when transitioning from state B to state C, we need to analyze the process depicted in the P-V diagram.
State A is the initial state of the gas.
State B represents the gas at a higher pressure and volume.
State C represents the gas at a lower pressure and volume.
State D represents the gas at a lower pressure and volume.
The process is an isothermal process, meaning the temperature remains constant throughout the process.
The gas transitions from state A to state B, then to state C, and finally back to state A.
The work done during the process can be calculated using the formula W = ∫(p · dV).
For the process A→B and C→D, the work done is W = ∫(A to B) p · dV + ∫(B to C) p · dV + ∫(C to D) p · dV.
Since the temperature is constant, the work done is zero for each segment of the process.
The temperature remains constant throughout the process, so the thermal motion of gas molecules remains constant.
The pressure increases from A to B and then decreases from B to C.
The pressure decreases from B to C, which means the thermal motion of gas molecules becomes more intense when transitioning from state B to state C.
Therefore, the thermal motion of gas molecules becomes more intense when transitioning from state B to state C.
